video_title: Philippines reports record-high 22,366 COVID-19 cases
description:
Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/@Rappler/

More videos on Rappler: https://www.rappler.com/video The Philippines reports a new record-high of 22,366 fresh COVID-19 cases in one day on Monday, August 30. This is the fifth straight day the new cases recorded by the Department of Health exceeded the 15,000-mark. 

READ: https://www.rappler.com/nation/coronavirus-cases-philippines-august-30-2021 Follow Rappler for the latest news in the Philippines and around the world. 

Support independent journalism. You can help power our investigative fund by donating to our crowdfunding: https://donate.rappler.com/
video_transcript: the philippines reports a new record high of 22 366 fresh covet 19 cases in one day on monday august 30. this is the fifth straight day the new cases recorded by the department of health exceeded the 15 000 mark monday's jump in infections raises the country's total coven 19 case load since the pandemic began to almost 2 million the number of single day covet 19 infections recorded in august stood at 387 237 this tally is more than a twofold increase than the listed 176 406 infections reported in july the doh also recorded 222 fatalities bringing the total death toll to 33 330. meanwhile recoveries were up by 16 864 for a total of one million seven hundred ninety four thousand two hundred seventy eight the doh reports a positivity rate of twenty seven point five percent meaning one in four people tested turned out positive for the virus the philippines now has almost 1 800 known cases of the highly transmissible delta variant but there are concerns the actual number may be far higher as the philippine genome center is only sequencing a small percentage of the positive cases

video_title: Philippines closes borders to UK due to mutated coronavirus strain | ANC
description:
The World Tonight: The Philippines joins a growing list of countries which have banned the entry of travelers from the UK where a more infectious strain of the COVID-19 virus has been detected.

An infectious diseases expert warns the Philippines could see a bigger surge in the holiday cases should the mutated virus reach the country.

consistently poor also out while the other half are just transient poor or those who are who just moved into poverty because of some Shock next piece so what have been the government responses next so um the the government has legislated um two um important um legislation pieces of legislation by anyone and by any hand too uh by any hanwan to heal or buy any hand to heal as one act um was enacted in March 2020 granting the president's special powers to combat the code with 19 pandemic and as of June 2021 the total budget allocated for that was 394.4 billion pesos and about um you know 96.8 percent has been dispersed as of uh June 2021 and we can see that most of it has actually been allocated to the swd and that's actually uh mostly uh sap and among other um subsidies to um to the individuals and Families in addition bayanihan two um or by any hand to recover as one act was also enacted and that was in September 2020 providing for pandemic response and Recovery interventions and the budget allocation for that was 240 214.1 billion and uh about 89 of that has been disbursed as of June 2021 and you can see that um for this particular um uh fund um a large part of it went to SSS next so what were the emergency measures implemented during the ecq um and these were anchored and emergency measures provided under the bayanihan one so we have um different cash assistance programs including the social amelioration program rice Farmers financial assistance program we have the covid-19 adjustment measures program for OFW and workers in the foremost sector implemented by the department of labor and employment we also have in-kind assistance um you know from owa Transportation food accommodation for our overseas workers um agricultural products to LG use by the Department of Agriculture we have the free bus ride program for health workers from the Department of Transportation laboring Sakai program and point-to-point bus augmentation scheme uh system from the mmda and food and non-food items provided by bswd in addition we have the wage subsidy for small businesses um implemented by the from the of this is under the small business which subsidy program for workers in the formal sector since programs provided by the Department of Agriculture and the department of trade and Industry the latter primarily for medium micro small and medium Enterprises we also have the emergency employment program so I think this Advantage displaced workers um project which aims to employ displaced workers and finally we also have um the program of SSS which provides Calamity loans um of up to 20 000 pesos next um so um we can see that um actually a lot of programs has been um have been implemented by the government and to assess low-income families displaced workers farmers and ofws among others who were affected by the pandemic and this chart just shows um how much is allocated um Target beneficiaries number of Target beneficiaries as well as the benefits given and let me just focus on the social amelioration program um emergency subsidies program um for this particular one there were two trenches of assistance given to um low-income families um and the first tranche uh covered about 18 million um families so you can imagine it's more than half of the total number of families and then the second trans covered slightly lower number of families on 14 million and the benefit given was about five thousand to um eight thousand [Music] um I don't have time to discuss all of them so I let me just go to to the next um slide um because this is something that uh we would like to to focus on because of the size of the program so this was uh the target beneficiaries of sap um were primarily for families registered in the pandavian Familia Filipino program or the four piece it was also intended to cover informal economy workers such as the self-employed small small scale producers and Distributors and also those belonging to vulnerable sectors such as senior citizens persons with disability pregnant and lactating women solo parents or versus Filipinos in distress and Indigent indigenous peoples I think you will already have a sense that um while this is I think very good you can already Imagine The Challenge in terms of identifying and locating all of this target beneficiaries um so that's one of the the major um challenges in implementing such a a big program covering um so many Target beneficiaries and as I mentioned the financial assistance amounted to 5000 to 8 000 depending on the regional minimum wage rate where the building fishery is is located next so um what we did was to simulate what would be the impact of this cash transfers from the social amelioration program and as we can see um here if you look at the first few um uh grows if the poverty incidence is projected to be poverty incidents among families is projected to be 16 without the social amelioration program with the cash transfer from this program it is projected to go down to 12.2 percent so very significant decline in poverty incidents because of the sheer size of the the amount the cashels were given as well as the large number of beneficiaries covered by by this program and similarly the poverty incidents among population would have gone down from 21.5 to 17.3 because of that cash transfer next piece so there were other government responses or Mobility restrictions um due to localized lockdown Community quarantines there was also efforts to improve awareness so there were a lot of information dissemination campaigns um there were General guidelines issued so creation of a national action plan primarily on test Trace entry and there was also Health System supports augmentation of human resources for health and expansion of facilities for treatment and isolation and protections including so um let me just share some issues and concerns in the pandemic response um next so for instance in communication issues we find that the communication interventions for covid-19 response in the Philippines can be characterized Associated incoherent big and confusing and the details are actually in one of the papers in this volume um as authored by Dr Sheila CR there's also lack of expanded and targeting testing and aggressive contact tracing so the country lagged in contact tracing and ramped up testing which are among the more effective response Strategies employed in most in most countries also the country was the government was late in implementing much needed preventive measures of the onset of the Health crisis the implementation of community quarantines became the go-to response Whenever there is an impending search of cases unfortunately lockdowns were complemented with weak contact tracing and testing efforts next um there were also um issues related to data so having clear accurate timely and granular data is important to identify appropriate response strategies and policies promptly unfortunately serious data issues were evident in the Philippines data issues were also observed in targeting beneficiaries for the provision of assistance to affected individuals and families which in turn led to delays in the distribution of AIDS so as I mentioned earlier you know um trying to identify and locate 18 million eligible families which was quite a challenge um inadequate consultation Republicans professionals and experts led to poorly plan policies that are in contrast with the advice of medical experts and also there's a lack of strongly coordinated implementation framework so vertical and horizontal plans and operations were not fully aligned so what were some of the lessons learned by by sector and the reason we're we're trying to put them all together is because we're hoping that from this uh we could probably manage future shocks uh better so um in the area of health and Community quarantines we find that imposing Community quarantives or lockdowns is helpful but not sufficient in suppressing the outbreak I will let Dr ulip discuss more um the other lessons and and findings in in the health sector when he does his presentation later today next in the area of Education I think our experience in terms of different learning modalities um is going to be um very useful um moving forward from from this pandemic and again Dr orbetta um is in a better position we can discuss the Lessons Learned in this particular sector next um and of course macroeconomic response is key not just during the pandemic but in terms of moving forward on our road to to recovery and um and what we've seen is that monetary easing public spending and certain demand substitution helped spur growth in some sub-sectors and Dr Maggie Gonzalez will be presenting us um the details um this afternoon as well now um let me just talk a little bit more about some of the other sectors because we don't have the opportunity to hear from the other uh chapters uh in terms of data ICT and digitalization we find that more granular data are necessary to formulate and Implement data-driven responses um the national government directly needs to strengthen digitalization strategies to improve the use and access to ICT and the government must accelerate investments in ICT infrastructure to prevent the worsening of inequalities in the education sector and the government plays a significant role in enhancing digitalization in the economy by supporting Financial Innovations to reach land bank and promoting digital payments in public transactions so this would help a lot in the distribution particularly of cash transfers the full implementation of the national ID system is a foundational digital ID system and it's linking to the existing social protection Information Systems is essential in ensuring the efficient and effective execution of Crisis related social assistance programs but let me point out that um you know having the national ID is not adequate to be able to identify and to identify eligible beneficiaries so you have to link it with existing Information Systems to better identify eligible beneficiaries next and in terms of social protection um uh social safety nets that are effective properly targeted and well distributed are necessary to help Filipino families cope with the damaging effects of the pandemic equally important or strong leadership and data-driven decision making and executing the pandemic response we also find that modifying existing Assistance programs instead of creating new ones with new mechanisms for implementation maybe a more efficient approach in crisis response and this would allow us to respond faster in light with the opposition of community quarantees the national government has also ensure that people have access to food and other necessities through massive safety nets programs and Advocate Universal Health Coverage can greatly help in future public emergencies especially health related ones and while emergency cash transfers and formal and food relief packages are needed to smooth consumption programs that will assist households to have jobs and we start their business are necessary especially if we want those who temporarily fell into poverty to be able to recover more quickly and move out of poverty emergency subsidies such as monetary assistance for the non-food items are essential to augment the needs of Filipino families during a pandemic and again this is something that's very important we always want to um be ready with a list of eligible beneficiaries for different programs so establishing interoperable databases across government agencies is vital in crafting effective And Timely policies during public emergencies and the national IED can actually provide that variable to be able to merge the different administrative databases and next and we also have the important role of local government units because the whole of government approach is necessary for implementing the pandemic response and um with that the communication as I mentioned something that's very important there's a need to harmonize messages used at the national local levels to ensure accuracy and consistency and a very important policies and protocols should be widely disseminated ahead of implementation dates so that everybody can adjust to new policies and and protocols and citizen engagement should be widely uh promoted and role of public policy information officers should be strengthened and um with that I would like to thank you and I'll turn it over to um Dr CR thank you

video_title: COVID-19 update, April 6: Infections on the rise in Indonesia, Philippines and Thailand
description:
COVID-19 infections are on the rise in parts of Southeast Asia. Indonesia has recorded more than 200 new cases -- its biggest single day increase so far. The total number of cases stands at nearly 2,500, with 209 deaths. President Joko Widodo has reiterated his call for Indonesians to wear face masks. He had previously rejected calls to lockdown cities, saying it would hurt the poor the most. Meanwhile, the Philippines has announced more than 400 new cases and 11 new deaths. The country now has 3,660 cases and 163 deaths. Thailand has reported 51 new coronavirus cases -- including 13 medical personnel -- and three more deaths.

Subscribe to our channel here: https://cna.asia/youtubesub

video_transcript: infections are on the rise in parts of Southeast Asia Indonesia recorded more than 200 new cases its biggest single-day increase so far and that pushes the total number of cases to nearly 2500 with 209 deaths president Joko Widodo has reiterated his call for Indonesians to wear face masks outside their homes he has previously rejected calls to lockdown cities saying it would hurt the poor the most but some local governments have sought permission to tighten restrictions on their own the Philippines has announced more than 400 new covered 19 cases as well as 11 new deaths there are now three thousand six hundred and sixty cases in the country with 163 deaths in Thailand there are 51 new coronavirus cases and three more deaths 13 of the new cases are medical personnel

video_transcript: the health department on friday july 16 logs 16 new cases of the coven 19 delta variant of these 11 are local cases this brings the total cases of delta variant in the country to 35. the health department says while local cases have been detected the doh could not say yet if there is a local transmission of the delta variant in the country meantime a day after announcing the quarantine classifications of different areas for the rest of july president rodrigo duterte on friday july 16 changes the restrictions on some areas iloilo province iloilo city kageyande oro in gingo city in misamis oriental are now placed under enhanced community quarantine or ecq the strictest form of lockdown in the philippines until july 31. meantime the general community quarantine or gcq with heightened restrictions classification in the province of antique has been extended from july 22 to july 31. misamis oriental which is currently under modified gcq has been rolled back to a stricter gcq with heightened restrictions classification until the end of the month in related news the philippines receives its second shipment of 250 800 modernist covet 19 vaccine thursday july 15.

video_title: Duterte: Philippines' first COVID-19 vaccine might come from China | ABS-CBN News
description:
President Rodrigo Duterte said Thursday the Philippines' first vaccine for the novel coronavirus might come from China, where the infectious disease originated as well.

Duterte, in a taped address aired Friday, appealed to Filipinos for patience, saying he hopes that the situation would go "back to normal" by December.

video_title: First-ever Olympic gold lifts COVID-weary Philippines
description:
The winner of the Philippines' very first Olympic gold medal has returned to a euphoric country.
Weightlifter, High-duh-lynn Diaz won a long-awaited gold on Monday.
But it didn't come without political struggles.
Al Jazeera's Jamela Alin-dogan reports from Manila.  

- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/
- Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/
- Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
video_transcript: she bore the weight of her country's expectations and lifted the spirits of embattled weary filipinos jaidelin diaz is the first filipino to ever win an olympic gold medal heidel's victory is more than its weight in gold it came at a time that this country truly is beyond being on its knees it is at the throes of death but she was not always revered by this administration two years ago she appealed in public for more financial assistance for her olympic bid later on heidel's name was included on what is now known as the ouster plot matrix a diagram linking journalists and activists to a conspiracy overseen by drug lords to oust president rodrigo duterte from office now she faced an administration that profusely congratulates her and yet refuses to apologize gold is gold let by guns be by guns and dwell solely on your victory since the philippines joined the modern games of the olympiad in 1924 it had only won a total of 10 olympic medals for decades philippine sports has been held back by neglect and misplaced priorities corruption is seen as another problem too my advice to sports bodies is to listen and study what athletes need the needs in the 1980s are different to now we are talking about winning more medals in the olympics experts say the philippines should focus more on combat sports where filipinos have always excelled like boxing and taekwondo and not just focus on sports that measure time and distance like swimming and track and field many here believe heideln's victory will reignite support for filipino athletes but her inclusion in duterte's drug list matrix has also put her alongside other women who have stood their ground against duterte's administration despite repeated attacks and threats people here say that's because in this country sometimes the last one standing is a woman jamella lindogen al jazeera manila

video_transcript: the philippine government starts giving the first shots of a coronavirus vaccine on monday march 1. nurse cher los santos legally administers the first covet 19 vaccine in the country to dr gerard legaspi director of the university of the philippines philippine general hospital [Music] food and drug administration director general eric domingo government medical advisor dr ed sal salvagna and vaccines are carlita galvez jr are also vaccinated monday vaccinations also take place among health workers at the long center of the philippines dr jose en rodriguez memorial medical center and sanitarium veterans memorial medical center philippine national police general hospital and victoriano luna medical center the vaccinations are part of the first batch of vaccines to arrive from china sunday the six hundred thousand doses of synovox coronavac are a donation from the chinese government the sinovac vaccine had an efficacy of 50.4 percent from trials in brazil involving health workers but phase 3 trials showed an efficacy rate of 65.3 percent to 91.2 percent among healthy individuals aged 18 to 59 years old the who earlier said the 50 efficacy rating is acceptable for vaccines though the duterte government targeted to start distributing vaccines by february the philippines is now the last country in southeast asia to start vaccinating its residents meantime president duterte says he will go to china to personally thank chinese president xi jinping for their vaccine donation when the pandemic settles down i wanted to do personally china has been good and the it the way that helping us right now i i suppose that a debt of gratitude should be paid by a personal visit in related news the arrival of over half a million vaccine doses of the astrazeneca vaccine from the global kovacs facility on monday is postponed health secretary francisco duke iii says this is because of a quote-unquote global supply problem w h okay

video_title: Philippine town marks ‘Mud People’ festival amid Covid-19 restrictions
description:
Subscribe to our YouTube channel for free here: 
https://sc.mp/subscribe-youtube

The Philippine town of Bibiclat in central Luzon celebrated the annual Taong Putik festival on June 24, 2021. The tradition to honour the town’s patron saint, John the Baptist, is also a time to pray for good health. Amid the Covid-19 pandemic, this year’s celebration was held without the usual large crowds. Instead people were encouraged to remain at home to receive their blessings from a priest who visited devotees outside their homes.

video_title: Philippine President Duterte's approval rating hits record high despite surging COVID-19 outbreak
description:
Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's approval rating has hit a record high, despite the surging COVID-19 outbreak. An independent survey has shown that 91% -- or nine in 10 Filipinos -- approve of both President Duterte's performance and personality. That's up from 78% in 2019. The Philippines has the worst COVID-19 outbreak in Southeast Asia, with over 320,000 confirmed cases. The economy is forecast to contract nearly 7% in 2020, the biggest drop since the 1980s.

Subscribe to our channel here: https://cna.asia/youtubesub 

Subscribe to our news service on Telegram: https://cna.asia/telegram

Follow us:
CNA: https://cna.asia
CNA Lifestyle: http://www.cnalifestyle.com 
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/channelnewsasia
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/channelnewsasia
Twitter: https://www.twitter.com/channelnewsasia
video_transcript: surging coronavirus outbreak an independent survey shows nine in ten filipinos approved of both president duterte's performance and personality and for more on this ebueno bernal joins us live from manila buena an overwhelming thumbs up it seems for the president despite the pandemic what's behind mr duterte's lasting popularity well the presidential communications office said that the results of this survey by independent polling firm pulse asia can be attributed to certain government policies including the one-year extension of the pandemic-related state of calamity to expedite fund disbursement and efforts to revitalize the economy but critics are also saying that in interpreting these survey results you have to look at social milieu and the climate of fear in the country in terms of airing descent is there an incentive for survey takers to be truthful in terms of airing that dissent and critics are highlighting a pattern of intimidation you've seen how critics have been jailed in the case of opposition senator laila de lima after drug-related charges were filed against her after she initiated the senate probe on the abuses alleged under the drug war or have been ousted in the case of chief justice maria lourdes sereno who also aired criticism against the drug war before her ouster supposedly for different reasons or even media personalities uh journalists and duterte critic maria reza convicted of cyber libel facing various other charges or even the largest broadcaster abs-cbn shut down after coming head-to-head with mr duterte over un-aired a political advertisement issues now on the other hand as well mr duterte has always been a hugely popular president if you're looking at those surveys by credible polling firms and even the pattern from the time he got elected in 2016 to the midterm elections in 2019 if you recall in 2016 he won by a landslide of 16 million votes on a platform of ending drug proliferation and criminality in the philippines within three to six months and in the 2019 midterm elections we saw that not one candidate from the leading oppositions late called secured a senatorial seat and instead we saw names or people who had no national legislative experience uh being elected into national posts largely on the basis of the support of the president including senator bongo who was the previous special um assistant to the president who was also a long-term aide of mr duterte when he was mayor of davao city in southern philippines and senator bato de la rosa who was the national police chief under mr duterte widely regarded as the architect of the philippine drug war in terms of what's at stake here um you see that a continued popularity of mr duterte could also mean a further consolidation of power and uh that that's very important in the philippines where politics is largely driven by public sentiment whoever is popular whoever is that figure others follow or shift alliances but also you have to ask what is the marginal benefit here because even in status quo mr duterte already has huge institutional support for example in the supreme court he has appointed 11 out of the 14 sitting justices there or even in congress uh in congress congress is dominated by his allies institutions that are ideally the checks and balance uh of the executive branch and that's essentially what a lawyer buddy gutierrez who is the spokesperson for the uh vice president lenny roberto from the opposition liberal party that's what he argued uh against the rebuke from presidential spokesperson harry roque when he said uh that mrs roberto lagged behind in those surveys uh because she was politicking uh amid a pandemic and um mr gutierrez said that the office of the vice president does not have uh the same institutional support as that of the president all right thanks for that update bruno bernal speaking to us from manila

video_title: Philippines celebrates Christmas with decorations, but Covid-19 cancels parties and big gatherings
description:
Subscribe to our YouTube channel for free here: 
https://sc.mp/subscribe-youtube

The Philippine government has urged people to tone down or skip festivities to prevent a surge of Covid-19 infections over the holiday season. Coronavirus-weary Filipinos were seen visiting Christmas decorations in the capital Manila on December 8, 2020.

https://subscribe.scmp.com

video_title: Philippines tallies 10,775 new COVID-19 cases
description:
Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/@Rappler/

More videos on Rappler: https://www.rappler.com/video The Philippines reports 10,775 new COVID-19 cases Wednesday, January 5, the highest since October 10, 2021. The health department says the cases could peak by the end of January.

video_transcript: the philippines reports 10 775 new covet 19 cases wednesday january 5 the highest since october 10 2021. the positivity rate is at 31.7 percent which means nearly one in three people tested were positive for covet 19. this is way above the five percent threshold set by the world health organization which indicates the spread of the virus is under control the health department says the cases could peak by the end of january in an interview with telerajo health under secretary maria rosario vergera says it is assumed that the omicron variant is already spreading in communities the doh also projects the cases will continue to double every day based on their daily tallies the spike in cases come since the philippines records a total of 14 cases of the omicron variant with three of these being local cases infectious disease specialist dr ronjin solante in an earlier interview said one omicron case can infect up to 16 people delta infects up to eight meanwhile the united states sets a global record of almost 1 million new coronavirus infections on monday january 3. the 978 856 new infections are nearly double the country's peak just a week ago as the highly contagious omicron variant shows no sign of slowing

video_transcript: the asian development bank on friday march 12 approves a 400 million dollar or 19.4 billion peso loan for the philippines to purchase covet 19 vaccines the philippines is the first recipient under the adb's nine billion dollar asia-pacific vaccine access facility or appvax the latest funding brings the adb support for the philippines pandemic response to around 3 billion dollars in loans and grants in related news novovax's covet 19 vaccine is 96 effective in preventing cases in a late stage trial conducted in the united kingdom the company also announces its vaccine is 86 effective in protecting against the more contagious united kingdom variant this brings a combined 90 effectiveness rate overall based on data from infections of both versions of the coronavirus

video_title: Philippines starts long-delayed Covid-19 vaccination programme using free Chinese Sinovac jabs
description:
Subscribe to our YouTube channel for free here: 
https://sc.mp/subscribe-youtube

The Philippines rolled out its long-stalled coronavirus vaccination programme on March 1, 2021, the day after Manila took delivery of its first batch of free jabs from China. Health care workers, police and military personnel were the first to receive the Sinovac shots, prompting thanks from Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte. Manila’s Food and Drug Administration approved the vaccine for emergency use on people aged 18-59, but 75-year-old Duterte has ruled out taking it himself because of his age. Authorities also advised against use of the Chinese vaccine for health care workers, citing its low efficacy rate. The Chinese vaccine has not been popular among Filipino hospital staff, with one survey indicating that 94 per cent would prefer jabs from Pfizer or AstraZeneca.

video_title: Webinar #10 |  COVID-19 and Children: The Experience of Southern Philippines Medical Center, Davao
description:
Webinar #10 | Stop COVID Deaths: Clinical Management Updates | COVID-19 and Children: The Experience of Southern Philippines Medical Center, Davao

The University of the Philippines in partnership with Philippine Health Insurance Corporation (PhilHealth) and the UP Manila NIH National Telehealth Center would like to invite you to join the Fight Against COVID-19! 

The UP Webinar Series "STOP COVID DEATHS: Clinical Management Updates" is scheduled EVERY FRIDAY from 12nn to 2pm. 


Webinar #10: “COVID-19 and Children: The Experience of Southern Philippines Medical Center, Davao”
Ma. Delta S. Aguilar
SPMC Pediatric Infectious Disease Specialist
June 26, 2020 (Friday) 12nn

How has the pandemic impacted on children?  Children may be hidden victims of COVID-19 as lockdowns have made it difficult for mothers to bring their children for regular check-ups or vaccination. Food may be scarce leading to malnutrition. Globally, child abuse has been reported as an effect of being kept at home under stressful conditions. Children may develop anxiety and not know how to express their fears and concerns.  Children may be afraid for the people who care for them, especially if their parents are health workers.

Children can also get COVID-19.  How do we care for children who get the infection? What should doctors watch out for in children who are exposed to adults with COVID-19?
The literature states that most children who get COVID-19 have a mild or even asymptomatic illness, there are new reports that some children may have a multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C)  can lead to life-threatening problems with the heart and other organs in the body. Early reports compared it to Kawasaki disease, an inflammatory illness that can lead to heart problems and cause severe illness

On the other hand, the symptoms of COVID-19 can mimic other types of infections.  How can we differentiate COVID-19 in children from other infectious diseases?
How about children with other types of diseases like cancer or rheumatoid arthritis who may be at risk for getting COVID-19?  How can we protect them?

COVID-19 and children will focus on how to protect and care for children during the pandemic.

video_title: Indonesia surpasses Philippines for Southeast Asia’s largest Covid-19 case numbers and death toll
description:
Subscribe to our YouTube channel for free here: 
https://sc.mp/subscribe-youtube

Indonesia has surpassed the Philippines as the nation with Southeast Asia’s highest number of Covid-19 infections and related deaths. As of October 19, 2020, Indonesia had reported more than 365,200 cases and 12,600 deaths, while the Philippines had confirmed over 359,100 infections and a death toll of 6,600. 
 

Support us:
https://subscribe.scmp.com

Website:  https://www.scmp.com

Twitter:  https://twitter.com/scmpnews
Instagram:  https://instagram.com/scmpnews
Linkedin:  https://www.linkedin.com/company/south-china-morning-post/

video_title: Philippines' COVID-19 tally surpasses 2 million with 14,216 new cases | 24 Oras
description:
The Philippines' COVID-19 tally breached the two million mark on Wednesday as the Department of Health reported 14,216 new infections, raising the country's total caseload to 2,003,955.

24 Oras is GMA Network’s flagship newscast, anchored by Mike Enriquez, Mel Tiangco and Vicky Morales. It airs on GMA-7 Mondays to Fridays at 6:30 PM (PHL Time) and on weekends at 6:00 PM. For more videos from 24 Oras, visit http://www.gmanetwork.com/24oras.

video_title: Clean beaches return to Philippine island after Covid-19 pauses tourism
description:
Subscribe to our YouTube channel for free here: 
https://sc.mp/subscribe-youtube

Clean beaches and previously dwindling wildlife populations are returning to Boracay, an ‘island paradise’ of the Philippines. As the country continues to be closed off from international tourists due to the pandemic, the island is starting to recover from earlier environmental impacts of over-tourism, including garbage pile-ups, rampant land encroachment, traffic and air pollution.

Support us:

video_title: Philippines limits inbound travel for one month due to COVID-19 | UAE news
description:
Inbound travel to the Philippines for foreign nationals and returning Filipinos who are non-overseas Filipino workers (OFWs) has been suspended for one month, from March 20 until April 19. The decision was made following a directive from the Philippine National Task Force Against COVID-19 (NTF) on Tuesday.

Read the full story here: https://bit.ly/30T1jXA

Subscribe to Gulf News on YouTube and watch more of our videos: https://www.youtube.com/user/GulfNewsTV

See more videos at https://gulfnews.com/videos
Read more Gulf News stories here: https://bit.ly/2HLJ2km

#UAEnews #Philippines #Covid19
video_transcript:
Inbound travel to the Philippines for foreign 
nationals and returning Filipinos who are   non-overseas Filipino workers has been suspended 
for one month, from March 20 until April 19. The decision was made following a directive from   the Philippine National Task Force 
Against COVID-19 (NTF) on Tuesday. The Philippine government has 
also ordered international   inbound arrivals at Manila’s Ninoy Aquino 
International Airport shall be limited   to a maximum of 1,500 passengers per day – for 
all airlines combined – from March 18 to April   19, 2021, in line with a directive issued by 
the Civil Aeronautics Board in the Philippines. The National Task Force noted, that the 
Philippines has recorded on March 15 a total of   5,404 new cases of COVID-19, the highest 
daily spike in the last six months. As a result, the Philippines will 
suspend the entry of foreigners   and returning overseas Filipinos who are non-OFWs. There are exemptions, which include:
Holders of 9(C) visas (seafarers)  Medical repatriation and their escort/s endorsed
Distressed returning overseas Filipinos  Emergency and humanitarian cases
Flight suspensions

video_transcript: welcome back to my channel my name is Jocelyn and for today's topic I'm going to discuss the travel requirements for All Foreign Nationals entering Philippines but before we get started please like this video and if you haven't subscribed to my Channel Please Subscribe and hit that notification Bell I always welcome new subscribers let's get started in this video I'm going to discuss the travel requirements for vaccinated foreign tourists going to Philippines first you need to determine if you are going to need a visa if you are a national of a country included under executive order number 408 then no Visa is required however if your country is not included then you will have to apply for a Visa online you will have to use visa.gov.ph now contact the Philippine Embassy covering your residence for additional documents for applying for a Visa for purposes of this video I'm going to classify foreign Nationals based on whether they are being required a Visa or not so there are specific countries listed under executive order number 408 so this is important because Nationals from this list of countries are not required a Visa but you will be entitled to a 30-day free stay in the Philippines please take note if you are coming from Visa free countries the Visa is free and you are entitled to stay not later than 30 days in the Philippines for foreign tourists the first classification are those Nationals of countries included under executive order number 408 and these are specific countries you will be entitled to a 30 days of visa-free stay in the Philippines and there is no charge to the Visa and you will get the visa upon arrival it will be stamped to your foreign passport the second classification are foreign tourists and these are Nationals who are not included under eo408 so you must apply for a 9A Visa abroad from Philippine consulate covering your residence you must also use the new online visa system and you must pay the visa fee the next requirement is that you must have a foreign passport that is valid for at least six months meaning to say your passport is not expiring within the last six months before the date of your travel also return or onward ticket will be required for foreign tourists and the ticket must not be later than 30 days you can always extend before the expiration the next requirement is that you must have e-travel registration if you are going to Philippines and the purpose is to provide a digital or printed copy of the barcode for express lane purposes now if you are an unvaccinated passenger you can still enter Philippines but you must provide negative tests within 24 hours of departure or upon arrival if you are 15 years old and above now if you are vaccinated you must provide acceptable proof of vaccination booster shot is not required to be fully vaccinated so if you are fully vaccinated you don't need a booster shot and you won't need a negative test to enter Philippines who needs to present a negative antigen test so here are the travel rules you must present negative antigen tests prior to departure or upon arrival and this is required for all Filipinos and non-filipinos 15 years old and older here are the specific requirements for the negative antigen test for unvaccinated passengers and this is based on iatf resolution number 168 so the requirement is that either you must have a remotely supervised or laboratory-based rapid antigen negative test result and this antigen test must be administered and certified by a healthcare facility laboratory clinic or Pharmacy or similar establishment also the negative test must be taken within 24 hours prior to the date and time of departure from the country of origin or first Port of embarkation in a continuous travel to Philippines excluding layovers provided that he or she has not left the airport premises or has not been admitted into another country during such lay over the rule is that the negative antigen test must be presented by Filipinos and non-filipinos 15 years old and older what if you fail to present a negative pre-departure testing you will be required to undergo a laboratory-based antigen test upon arrival at the airport the Philippine government will consider you a fully vaccinated individual for covid-19 more than or equal to two weeks after having received the second dose in a two dose series or more than or equal to two weeks after having received a single dose vaccine here are the acceptable covet vaccines in the Philippines biotech Pfizer convidesha vaccine epivac Corona Johnson vaccine moderna Nova wax Oxford AstraZeneca Pfizer community Farm cyanovac Sputnik light and Sputnik 5. another requirement is you will still have to wear a mask because airplane is considered public transportation number seven if you are a passenger arriving at Naia terminal 1 please fill out the online costs of declaration form you can also have the option of paper form if you are going to fill out the online customs declaration form you must go to the Bureau of Customs website customs.gov.ph and you must find I declare scroll down on the website and click on I declare and go to I declare a web page so you can fill out the electronic form There are rules to remember when filling out the electron customs declaration form you must fill it out within 48 hours prior to arrival and click the E CBD application acknowledge the privacy policy and fill out the form by providing your personal flight information once completed click submit and you must download the QR code and it will be sent to your email address you can print it or present it to the Customs officer proceed to Green Lane if you have nothing to declare or to the red lane if you have Goods to declare if you recently traveled in the Philippines or if you plan to travel and you are a first time traveler in the Philippines please share your thoughts in the comment section below and if there's any rule that is holding you back from traveling please also let us know in the comment section below I would really appreciate it if you have any other questions or comments please post them down below and I will get back to you as soon as I can again thank you guys for supporting my channel and if you haven't liked this video please give it a big thumbs up and if you haven't subscribed to my Channel Please Subscribe and hit that notification Bell I always welcome new subscribers thank you guys for watching I hope everyone is staying safe and have a great day

description:

The Philippines reimposed a strict Covid-19 lockdown starting August 4, 2020. The decision follows a call from health care workers for stronger measures to fight the spread of the coronavirus in the country and to prevent the health care system from collapsing under the pressure of a rising number of new cases. On August 2, the country  confirmed a daily record high of about 5,000 infections.

video_title: The Unseen Cost Of Philippines' Pandemic Baby Boom | Undercover Asia | CNA Documentary
description:
In the Philippines, the pandemic has resulted in an explosion of unwanted pregnancies, because access to birth control was curtailed. Many of these unwilling mothers are teenagers, some just 15. 

Most women who are too poor to raise another child, unwed, or too young to bear any children seek the help of backstreet abortionists and abortion pill traders. Others turn to peddling their unwanted child. What must be done to stop the trend?

Watch more Undercover Asia: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLkMf14VQEvTb786lOB4Qsr5zp58blidcw

==========
About Undercover Asia 9: CNA's award-winning investigative series Undercover Asia returns for the ninth season to uncover two disturbing trends in China and the unexpected fallout from the pandemic in Asia and beyond.
================
#CNAInsider #CNAInvestigates #UndercoverAsiaCNA #Philippines #FamilyPlanning

and when there are lockdowns for some women backstreet abortionists are heaven-sent desperation and ignorance force women to put their faith and their lives in the hands of those they barely know [Music] hmm [Music] in the philippines all abortions are illegal and in this staunchly catholic nation it's also widely seen as a sin but driven underground backstreet abortions remain as popular as ever after months of lockdown with her husband and no access to contraception mary jane has been left with an unwanted pregnancy she feels her only way out is to rely on marika to help her abort according to one study for every month in community quarantine induced abortion cases are likely to soar by an additional 17 000. [Music] it is mary jane takes a handful of pills from the midwife marika these are cytotec they're abortion pills containing the banned drug misoprostol after the drug is consumed marika will administer pincer strokes on mary jane's belly these will crush the three-month-old fetus foreign after a few minutes mary jane starts to bleed foreign [Music] [Applause] later mary jane's friend will help her bury her three-month-old fetus in a shallow grave near her house [Music] induced abortions in the time of pandemic basically it boils down to poverty of course for sex sometimes incest rape for those who don't have access to post-abortion care it's very dangerous for these women these women who had illegal abortions usually can have hemorrhage their uterus might be taken out unnecessarily because of the infection or worse due to hemorrhage they can die of the illegal abortion done on them for those who have no means for an illegal abortion there is another option sell the baby in the philippines unborn or newborn babies are being traded under the guise of adoption social media is rife with posts from expectant moms looking to give up their baby and couples looking to adopt [Music] undercover asia puts up a plea on facebook to appeal for a baby to adopt within a week we have two responses from so-called bee moms or birth mothers [Music] we arranged to meet one of them she's six months pregnant but already prepared to sell her child foreign [Music] [Music] prior to pandemic illegal adoption has been really rampant but during this time illegal adoption has been through online basically it's easier it's more accessible and it's faster the department of social welfare and development or dswd implements the country's adoption system but since 2020 the dswd has received just four complaints of illegal child trafficking we do not have the real numbers of those cases of illegal adoption there could be many cases but it's just that it's not reported to us [Music] social media usually pedals unborn babies when it comes to buying babies already born manny is the man to go to he's a middleman matching childless couples with poor families who have infants to sell manny organizes deals including the price time of exchange and the fixing of paperwork since the start of 2020 manny has sold over seven babies on the black market foreign through another middleman like manny undercover asia is introduced to a mother who's looking to sell her newborn the 47 year old called herself nancy permanente foreign nancy lives with a mother who makes just three dollars a day working as a garbage collector [Music] the price on her baby would amount to three months of their household income nancy became pregnant during the lockdown endless covet 19 lockdowns kept nancy away from vital sexual reproduction health services [Music] foreign official adoption in the philippines is a complex process that takes years pandemic travel bans court closures and stay-at-home orders for government workers have made the process even harder birth mothers desperate for money or unable to add yet another child to their brood resort to desperate measures regardless of the consequences it could be physical adoption it could be sexual adoption because there was no assessment done thorough assessment done to really ensure that these adoptive parents are really fit to take care of the child and to provide for that child there is the tendency that this children who were illegally adopted may also be abused [Music] [Music] 14 days after undercover asia spoke to nancy she finds a buyer for her baby they're a childless couple from manila she's paid 196 u.s dollars and the baby broker takes a 20 commission [Music] on [Music] unwanted pregnancies aren't just burdening poor families in the philippines they're also putting a strain on a healthcare system that's already stretched to the limit by the pandemic [Music] um as a result of covet 19 lockdowns 34 year old hershey gonzalez has spent 19 months in confinement with her unemployed husband with no regular access to birth control hershey is now expecting her ninth baby [Music] and [Music] m i think the trend in the number of pregnancies will continue we are expecting more women to be getting pregnant because the environment is conducive for reproduction and we will be handling a lot of pregnant women out of the lockdown dr jose fabelier memorial hospital is one of the world's busiest maternity wards this manila hospital is known as the baby factory before the pandemic more than 2 000 babies were delivered here every month but when covert 19 hit about a third of the maternity wards were shuttered midwives gynecologists and nurses were diverted to the front line to battle the surging number of covet 19 cases starting january we are supposed to open up but the omicron no barian came in and we are again on a limited capacity mode if it is already full in our maternity ward they can no longer refer high-risk pregnancies to our hospital because there's no more space [Music] with limited or no access to maternity wards during the pandemic it's a perfect storm for impoverished women like hershey for those who have more than five children they are usually at risk of having hemorrhage after birth because near uterus is overworked and these women having nine or more they are usually under nourished most of them have anemia have diabetes hypertension they also run the risk of having low birth weight babies premature babies there is our numerous but not wanting to jostle with others at maternity hospitals hershey is opting for a home birth foreign 19 has swung a wrecking ball into the philippines family planning services it is likely to buck the philippines decade-long decline in birth rate with an expected surge in pregnancies after the pandemic [Music] hershey welcomed her ninth baby into the world [Music] [Music] foreign [Music] [Music] it's been two weeks since mary jane had a risky illegal abortion while she survived the abortion and escaped the economic consequences of an unwanted child the abortion left an emotional imprint which he could not erase [Music] [Music] [Music] foreign [Music] [Music] you

video_title: How Covid pushed the Philippines’ biggest bank to go digital
description: For the largest bank in the Philippines, embracing digital required a culture shift. Paul Siy, CTO of BDO Unibank, shares how digital technology and AI hold out promise for future banks. https://tinyurl.com/4c3hcvtn #Huawei #TransformTalks #Transform #WhoAreWe #ThisIsHuawei
video_transcript: you can't teach an old dog new tricks so goes the Western phrase meaning that for some people they're simply resistant to change and taking on Fresh opportunities well not BDO UniBank there's certainly a big dog they're the biggest bank in the Philippines and a relatively old job I should know on the same age as they are but here at the intelligent Finance Summit organized by Huawei and Shanghai when we spoke to bdo's head of infrastructure and operations Paul C he said they definitely learned new tricks in this era of digital transformation it's had to for this edition of transform talks while a thought leadership interview series I asked Paul what bdo's challenges had been and how they'd adapted it was very difficult in the beginning when we started during the pandemic we did not really have any tools in terms of being able to provide Digital Services in terms of let's say working from home or even providing our staff the necessary capabilities so that they can work remotely we changed all that very quickly during the pandemic we were able to deploy tools that will allow our people and our systems to be accessed remotely we beefed up our digital banking capabilities so that our clients if they choose to transact with us either digitally or in the branch can do that so it was it was challenging so one of the things that we did was we moved to a new data center we built a new data center infrastructure we allowed data to be replicated from one data center to another which was as you know as a bank it's it's very important that your data is preserved whether it's running on data center a or date Center B and you could easily switch between those two areas once your application either goes down or you want to switch quickly to another data center the other thing that we did was really beef up our digital banking capabilities one of the things that we saw during the pandemic was a large frankly the the spike in the volume of users using mobile banking probably when from the normal to about two to three times that in a span of weeks through necessity through necessity because um because of the pandemic there was a lockdowns I think most most cities most countries experience that and the only way that you can transact and do transactions was digitally so what productivity gains has all this enabled you to have as a bank and for your customers and consumers well one of the things that we recently deployed with Huawei was the Wi-Fi we we put Enterprise Wi-Fi in a lot of our locations you can just imagine all of our users used to be connected via a cable right now they can work more freely with the Wi-Fi that we put up with with huawei's help uh the other thing that we've done was going back to the data center scenario where we replicate databases from one data center to another without any lag and that that has really helped us a third project that we're working on now is moving our backups from the old traditional tape into storage media which will allow us to really manage a lot of the risk and also the ability to quickly backup and restore a lot of the data that they might need it's interesting you've obviously really adapted to these changes and embraced them and as a result given a better service are you surprised that not all banks or Legacy Banks established banks have been quite so agile well one of the things that I've always sort of prophesies or at least you know shared with my team was a change in culture right frankly the the the four years that I've been there the first two years was really focusing on changing the culture changing the culture of the team changing the way the team thinks and it's really breaking down the ability to accept change change is is key especially now I mean just look at what's happening in in the technology world with the implementation of AI you know the speed at which technology is changing is just amazing right and if you as a an organization is not culturally adapted to change you're going to have a very difficult time adapting to the changes in technology and to the changes in the world there's a kind of adapt or die isn't there and what will AI do do you think you mentioned AI That's clearly going to bring even more changes right what would you look to Huawei to do to assist you on the impact of that one of the key things that we're looking to partner with Huawei on is it's really putting more AI into into the storage into the networks that we purchased from Huawei uh maybe looking at more adaptive capabilities in terms of looking at where the faults could be where the problems might lie or or predictive analysis in terms of if there are issues that will happen in the near future it would alert you in addition we're looking at other ways that we can use AI we have we're trying to build chat Bots now that are very much conversational you might think that you're talking to a person when it's actually is an AI bot behind it and it holds a lot of promise

video_title: COVID-19 vaccine in the Philippines expected April 2021 – FDA | Evening wRap
description:
Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/@Rappler/

More videos on Rappler: https://www.rappler.com/video Today on Rappler – the latest news in the Philippines and around the world:

- FDA says 'best case scenario' of COVID-19 vaccine in PH is April 2021. The Food and Drug Administration or FDA says the earliest possible availability of a coronavirus vaccine in the Philippines would be by April 2021.

- Cusi overtakes Mark Villar as Cabinet member with highest net worth in 2019. Energy Secretary Alfonso Cusi overtook fellow billionaire and Public Works Secretary Mark Villar as the member of the Duterte Cabinet with the highest net worth in 2019.

- 'Enough is enough': China attacks US at Security Council. China lashes out at the United States at a high-level United Nations meeting.

- Julia Barretto files complaint vs Jay Sonza, Liza Soberano files criminal complaint over online user's rape remark. Actress Julia Barretto on Friday, September 25, filed a complaint against former broadcaster Jay Sonza days after the broadcaster falsely claimed she was pregnant, while Liza Soberano formally filed a criminal complaint against an online user who made a rape comment about her.

- FALSE: Photo shows Arroyo in better condition during Duterte's term. The photo of Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo surfing was taken in 2005, years before both Aquino and Duterte assumed the presidency.

video_title: The Philippines Receive Over 3M U.S.-Donated Moderna COVID-19 Vaccines
description:
Nandito kami para sa inyo. 🇵🇭🇺🇸

More than three million doses of U.S.-donated Moderna COVID-19 vaccine arrived in the Philippines on August 3, delivered through COVAX. This brings the total number of vaccines received by the Philippines through COVAX to more than 13.3 million doses, including more than 6.2 million doses donated by the U.S. from its own supplies. #USPHThrivingAt75 #OneWorldProtected

Read: https://ph.usembassy.gov/president-duterte-and-cabinet-officials-welcome-arrival-of-3-million-us-provided-moderna-vaccines-to-the-philippines/
video_transcript:
Let us beat COVID-19 together at maraming salamat po sa inyong lahat. On August 3, 2021, President Duterte and Cabinet officials joined Chargé d’Affaires John Law to welcome the arrival of more than 3 million U.S.-donated Moderna vaccines to the Philippines, delivered through COVAX. This latest shipment brings the total doses received by the Philippines under COVAX to over 13 million, including more than 6.2 million doses donated by the United States from its own supplies. The United States is determined to do all that we can to help end the COVID-19 pandemic globally. As the biggest contributor to the COVAX facility, the U.S. has facilitated the delivery of more than 13 million vaccines to the Philippines. For decades, our two nations have been allies and partners. For generations, Filipinos and Americans have been friends and family. Despite the challenges and difficulties we’ve endured over the past year and a half, our nations and our friendship are stronger for having faced them side by side. Nandito kami para sa inyo.
Maraming salamat. For more information on U.S. COVID-19 assistance to the Philippines, visit ph.usembassy.gov

And and I I I posted  that ah this has to do with  many businesses that being able  to operate ah normally in two  thousand twenty-one. Including  malls, ah malls, big  restaurants, and real estate  businesses, many of which are  owned by the country's rich  families. On the other hand,  many small entrepreneurs  engaged in community markets  including Vibrant Community  Markets.  and perhap s, this is the reason  for the decline in, the  contribution of entrepreneurial  income, In addition, Perhaps  which inequality increased  because the ECQ favored ah wage  workers who can do their jobs  remotely. And these are mainly  the college graduates who  typically have higher incomes  to begin with.  I now describe the potential  for longer term impact on  inequality of the COVID-19  experience.  As we know the COVID-19  pandemic and the ECQ suddenly  forced students in all grade  levels into remote learning  mode. And and given the short  time, the education system and  teachers have had to prepare  the quality of remote learning  is likely inferior to to the  face to face learning that was  in place before the pandemic.  Ah and this has a potentially  negative impact on the future  productivity of the cohort of  students whose education were  affected by the pandemic. And  that's on future inequality. Uh  moreover, because access to  remote learning, resources is  highly unequal with less access  to those from lower income  households, students from lower  income households are likely to  suffer greater learning  deficits.  this table shows ah ownership  of ah personal computer or  tablet, cell phone ah broadband  connection, TV and radio by  household income queen tile in  two thousand twenty. Ah it  shows ownership of ah personal  computer and tablet is  tremendously unequal. Ownership  of ah cell phones which is  likely inferior to personal  computers for remote learning  purposes. Is more evenly  distributed but still favor  those in the highest income  quintile. One fourth of  households in the lowest  quintel reported not having any  cell phone. access to broadband  connection was even scarcer and  also unequal. With less than  half of all households,  reporting having this type of  connection. Access to mobile  data is not available from from  the Apis data but is also  likely to be highly correlated  with income. Even TV ownership  is still unequal with close to  40% of households in the lowest  quintel. Reporting having a TV  compared to 95% for those in  the top quintile. The AGO only  reported owning a radio. By the  way, let me acknowledge, our  student, Simon Dubaco, for,  for,  of poor children is affected  disproportedly because of  substantially less access to  learning  to work from home opportunities  and online training  opportunities. Again, this  could impact both ah short term  and longer term income and  non-income inequalities as  well.  As an immediate response to the  COVID-19 crisis, the  Philippines Congress enacted  the Bayanihan to heal as one  act in March 2 thousand twenty,  which among others sought to  provide to 18 million  low-income households and  emergency subsidy amounting to  between 5000 and 8000 ah pesos  for 2 months. So this was more  popularly known as ah DSWD ah  SAP for social MLA relation  program. Later the Philippines  Congress expanded  which was targeted to affected  OFWs. This table which is  computed from the FIS, shows  the incidence of benefits from  the four programs described  above, as of June 2 thousand  twenty. Of course, the programs  extended beyond June thousand,  June 2020. But the three months  from April to June 2 thousand  twenty, were very critical as  this was the, as this was the  period when the lockdowns were  most severe. And the  unemployment was at the, at the  record level. As of June 2  thousand twenty, only 46. 7% of  household of households  reported receiving a cash  grant. And though the incidence  of staff benefits was  progressive, meaning lower  quintiles, larger share  benefiting, it was perhaps not  progressive enough. As 45% of  households in the first and  second quintiles still did not  benefit. As of June 2 thousand  twenty. The Dole programs had  relatively fewer beneficiaries.  Campos aggressive as of June  2020 with higher income  quintile households having a  higher share of beneficiaries.  Well this this is to be  expected as higher income  households typically have  better educated workers who are  more likely to to be informal  sector jobs. Because camp  targeted ah formal sector  workers. To pad which was for  informal sector workers was  more progressive but still only  a very small share 1% or of  households in the law of  reported benefiting from the  program as of June two thousand  twenty. Acap was also  regressive as OFWs typically  come from higher income  households. And of course the  as you can see from the last  column the the the percent of  households receiving Acap is  also very very small. So to  conclude ah the COVID-19  pandemic has exactly the heavy  toll on the livelihood of many  Filipino households. I  presented evidence that some  subgroups of Filipino  households were more affected  than others, likely increasing  income and non-income  inequality in the country in  the short term, and potentially  in the longer term. Inequality  that existed prior to the  pandemic, such as, in access to  Social Security, in educational  attainment, in economic  opportunities, and access to  digital, digital technology has  contributed to the unequal  impact of the pandemic across  households. Most workers from  low-income households in the  country are in the form are in  the informal sector. Thus  lacking access to social  security and unemployment  insurance during the crisis.  Additionally, being in the  informal sector also meant that  they had difficulty availing of  government support but relied  on government databases in  identifying beneficiaries.  Moving forward, improving their  access to social and  unemployment insurance will  provide them a crisis safety  net and reduce the like of a  similar crisis in the future  exacting as much suffering in  the country. Ah there are  already many existing models of  how to expand social insurance  coverage for for informal  sector workers. Such as by  subsidizing social security  contributions for low income  earners. And by simplifying the  process of registration and  providing limited time tax  exemptions for micro, small,  and medium ah enter who  registered your enterprises and  workers. Narrowing the digital  divide is likewise critical in  pampering the rise in  inequality in the post COVID-19  era. Increase reliance on  digital technology via blended  learning for instance is likely  a permanent feature of the  educational system. Subsidizing  learning gadgets and access to  internet for students for lower  income households. Perhaps as  an attached program to the  already existing conditional  cash transfer program for  children. And pregnant from  poor households will reduce the  likelihood that they are left  behind. In poor in poor  communities, ah student access  to the internet can be provided  via community hubs such as the  Barangay Centers. Workers have  to be trained in digital skills  or more broadly in 21st century  skills to capacitate them to  engage in new employment  opportunities including remote  employment opportunities. And  also for entrepreneurs to allow  them or to enable them to reach  new markets that have emerged  in a world more reliant on  e-commerce. the long period of  time it broke from when the  government support programs  were announced the time the  benefits reached their intended  targets also have added  avoidable misery to the  pandemic. The problem cited was  the outdated and incomplete  database on which to base the  identification of  beneficiaries. So moving  forward, there is a need to  design the delivery system for  government support in times of  emergency to reach intended  beneficiaries quickly.  Utilizing digital payments if  possible. Transparently and  fairly. The design should be in  place before the next potential  national emergency utilizing  the national ID system,  registration that is now  ongoing, combined with other  government databases such as  the DSW displace Tahanan went  where proxy means testing is  required. Ah so undertaking  these actions will help ensure  that those who were behind  before  So, thank you very much, Doc  Chef, for those valuable  insights. Ah, showing the  relationship between or the  impact of COVID-19 on  inequality. At this point of  our program this afternoon, we  now open the floor for  questions. So, we have three  ways. Ah, you can raise your  hand so that I can call you.  And then you can personally ask  your question. Or you can also  type your question in the Zoom  chat. And I will read it. And  then to our participants  joining us in Facebook, you can  also type in the comment  section. And we will also ask  those questions. So to get the  ball rolling with respect to  our ah Q&A we have a first  question. Coming from one of  our Zoom participants, Mister  Steve Chavez. So the question  of Steve is the following. If  contribution to inequality by  entrepreneurship has declined,  then should it be interpreted  that income from  entrepreneurship has increased  because it shortens inequality?  should I answer no, Jenny?  Okay. Yes, Doctor Jen. Florence  yours. So, what it actually  means is that, the, the, the  inequality in, in,  entrepreneurial income has,  declined. So this can, this, I  mean, based on, based on the  observation, this likely  happened because the big  entrepreneurs such as for  example, the the owners of the  malls, the owners of big  restaurants, as mentioned  earlier, the owners of real  estate companies, their incomes  has declined during the during  the pandemic, especially during  the ECQ. At the same time, the  entrepreneurial income of a  lower income households, such  as those who engaged in,  vibrant community markets, for  example, has increased. So, the  combination of those is what  has made entrepreneurial income  more equal, which reduced its  contribution to total  inequality.  And we have a response. Thank  you Doc Jeff for answering that  question. And ah our  participants Steve thanks you  for that clarification on that  particular matter. Now we move  on to the second question. And  this is from Mister Carl  Galvez. Also a Zoom  participant. Hello Sir Jeff.  What does the data say if any  with regard to inequality in  education outcomes in basic and  higher education. And how can  we study it?  outcomes in terms of ah  performance. There's there's no  data yet. But outcomes in terms  of participation that you can  get from preliminary data you  can get from either the labor  for survey. Because that's done  quarterly. So you can monitor  what's happening more  frequently. And also to some  extent the annual poverty  indicator survey. But only up  to June two thousand twenty. Uh  Unfortunately, because of the,  based on the APS, you don't  really see any effect yet,  because, ah, ah, the APS was  conducted in July, when the  schools were having their  break. So when they were asked  whether they were enrolled or,  or not. Ah, or whether they,  they, ah, stop schooling  because of the, in, in the past  6 months. Ah, it, you cannot  really ah, capture yet, ah, the  effect of what happened during  the, in the following ah,  school year which is which was  when the main impact of the  pandemic occurred. Uh but again  just based on the observation  and also based on ah ah  preliminary analysis of the LFS  data. And just based on the  enrollment data that that that  was reported by by DepEd in two  thousand twenty. If I remember  correctly in K to 12, there was  a decline of about more than 2  million  ah, ah, or to, to skip  schooling, again, because of,  no, or, or poorer equality  access to remote learning. So  thank you Doc Jeff, for  answering that question. Again,  we invite our participants in  Zoom and in Facebook to ask  your questions. Uh at this  particular part of our program.  While we wait for that next  question. So allow me to throw  the the third question. Uh so  my question is after seeing how  the situation is right now. Um  what would you think would be  the urgent piece of legislation  or policy that would still be  doable as we close out the year  twenty twenty-two. With  respect, you know, minimizing  the adverse impact of COVID-19  on inequality.  So, I think I think their  ongoing efforts now in in  Congress. I I know that for for  example, there are moves to to  put in place unemployment  insurance. I think that that  will be a a big step, towards  improving ah social protection  for ah for ah lower income ah  households. and and definitely  if if there was unemployment  insurance in place, already, in  the country, before the  pandemic, the impact on poverty  and hunger will will not be as  bad. In other countries for  example, where unemployment  insurance was in place like,  some of our, Southeast Asian  neighbors like, Thailand, for  example, the impact of the  pandemic on, on, on household  welfare was not severe. So I  think, because that one's  already ongoing, the  unemployment insurance,  initiatives. I think that one  can be, ah ah pursued.  and and and related to the  earlier question of again there  there's not been a lot of  there's not been much of an  examination on on the on the on  the impact on the granular  impact of the pandemic on  enrollment. Uh perhaps now  there's more data by by DepEd  to see who who have dropped out  maybe some assessments of have  already been done as to what  was the impact on on learning  outcomes. And I I as soon as  possible ah  ah that may have occurred in  the learning of students during  the two years that ah they were  ah doing remote learning. So  either through ah tutorials ah  or or through ah ah  supplementary materials or even  on the job training. So I think  this should be ah done as  quickly as possible as soon as  possible so that ah this court  of students do not suffer the  long the long term impact of  the pandemic on their  productivity. So thank you Doc  Jeff for answering my question.  Now ah we have a raised hand  and I give the virtual floor to  Doctor Carl Handok of the UP  School of Economics. Doctor  Carl the floor is yours for  your question. Uh yeah, thank  you. Sorry, Jeff. I'm driving  and I'm malapit ng magcoding.  So, I'm taking the side  streets. So, again,  congratulations on the very  insightful presentation. I'm  really it's nice to know all  these things regarding poverty  and I have been crunching the  numbers myself And the curious  thing that I saw in your  presentation is that inequality  from 2018 to 2021 has decreased  spite of increasing poverty.  But  Poverty would have been higher  had ah you know poverty  incidents in Barm not  decreased. So there's a large  around 20 to 30 percentage  point decrease in  to ah income inequality. it's,  I, I'm curious to hear your  thoughts on the types of policy  that can sustain this poverty  this this huge poverty  reduction in farm. And if there  are any differences between  like, current policies that you  see which are in place and  other future policies which you  think can help sustain this. So  just curious to hear your  thoughts Jeff on this. Thanks.  Yan. Um I think that the the  large decline in in poverty in  farm it it merits further  examination. Uh I have not  looked at it deeply myself but  I think there's, I mean, I will  wait for the data, the, the  combined, the the the LFS data,  to see whether, ah, it's a,  it's a real change, it's a real  poverty decline, or something  more ah, artificial because of  some change in data. The only  possible thing that ah, I think  can account for, ah,  a larger decline in poverty  as  workers, agriculture, by giving  them ah lands. If they decide  to work as farmers.  So, yeah, nothing new, the  same, the same thing,  increasing the culture  productivity by providing the  necessary infrastructure  support, and also research and  development, and those things.  Thanks, Jeff. Thank you, Doctor  Andoc and thank you Doc Jeff  for answering the the question.  Um now we go back to the Zoom  chat as we have additional  questions. Uh we have a  question from Adrian Mitchell  Galano. How did COVID-19 affect  inequality in  to visit your, your doctors.  Especially the, the, the senior  citizen, because they were not  allowed to, to go out. This  means that, the only people who  can access, ah, ah, health care  were the people who who are,  who, who, who knew doctors, who  can call doctors, or later on,  who had access to ah, what do  you call that? Ah, ah,  telemedicine. Because ah in  late two thousand twenty1 ah,  the Department of Health  already made ah, tele  telemedicine more available. So  again, because, so, so the  pandemic affected the ah,  access to, to, ah, healthcare  in, in that way. That, that  poor households who had ah,  less access to communications  technology, were able to access  ah, health care less because  they couldn't access ah,  telemedicine  Thank you, doc, Jeff. So, in  the interest of time, we are  down to our last question. Ah,  so this last question is from  Mister Tommy Lazaro.
