video_title: How COVID-19 impacted the Philippines' food supply chain
description:
The COVID-19 pandemic has had a big impact on the food supply chain in the Philippines. 

In this video, we take a closer look at how the country has been affected, in order to better understand the role cold chain technology will play in supporting the Philippines going forward.

See all sources cited in the video here: https://cci-hub.org/index.php/2020/06/18/how-covid-19-impacted-the-philippines-food-supply-chain/#sources
Subscribe to the email newsletter: https://shecco.us2.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=386b7e45cdf899530469db859&id=fec81a5fa5&mc_cid=57e5c42004&mc_eid=%5bUNIQID%5d
Website: https://cci-hub.org/

Timestamps:
0:00 Introduction
0:44 Lockdown
1:41 Disruption
2:39 Farmers
3:28 Response
5:16 Investment
6:15 CCI-Hub

About the CCI-Hub:

The CCI-Hub is one of the main components of the “Global Partnership for improving the Food Cold Chain in the Philippines" project, implemented by the United Nations Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO) together with the Department of Environment and Natural Resources of the Philippines (DENR).

The Philippines’ Technical Education and Skills Development Authority (TESDA) has been selected as an official partner of the project and as the national entity to host the CCI-Hub at its central office located in Metro Manila.

The CCI-Hub serves as the project's main platform providing an ecosystem of technical resources, training, knowledge sharing and stakeholder collaboration. Its main objective is to increase adoption of best practice refrigeration and related services as well as communication throughout the food cold chain and to ensure a long-term impact of the project.

About the “Global Partnership for improving the Food Cold Chain in the Philippines":

One of the most pressing issues in developing countries is a faulty food cold chain, which results in massive food loss and underserved communities.

To address that problem in the Philippines, the project aims to identify, develop and stimulate the application of low-carbon, energy efficient refrigeration innovation technologies and business practices for use throughout the food cold chain (CC) to increase food safety and food security.   

It is funded by US$2 million from the Global Environment Facility (GEF), with US$25 million in co-financing (in-kind, grants and loans).

#Philippines #foodsupplychain #COVID

video_title: Hungry and homeless: Philippine 'jeepney' drivers hit by coronavirus
description:
Forced off the road by coronavirus lockdowns, Philippine "jeepney" drivers are now plying the streets of Manila on foot begging for money to feed themselves and their families. Jeepneys -- first made from leftover US jeeps after World War II -- are the backbone of the country's transport system, but many drivers are now out of work after the months-long virus restrictions crippled the Philippines' economy.

video_title: Philippines eyes corporate tax cut, stimulus vs COVID-19 | ANC
description:
The Philippines is considering an across the board cut in corporate income tax and a stimulus of up to P160 billion to save the economy from the COVID-19 pandemic, officials said.

video_title: LIVESTREAM: Philippines records 16 new COVID-19 cases, tally now at 49 | Replay
description:
The Philippines’ confirmed coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) cases continued to climb on Wednesday after the Department of Health (DOH) tallied 16 newly confirmed infections, bringing the total to 49.

video_title: President Duterte appeals for calm, vigilance as Philippines faces COVID-19 | News Patrol
description:
President Rodrigo Duterte on Thursday called on the public to be calm and vigilant, and observe proper hygiene to guard against COVID-19. In this video shared by the Presidential Communications team and aired on national TV, Duterte said people should wash their hands frequently, cover their mouth when sneezing and wear a face mask if they have cough.

video_title: Philippines to run anti-flu drug Avigan clinical trials on 100 COVID-19 patients | ANC
description:
Japan will provide enough anti-flu drug Avigan for 100 coronavirus disease patients for clinical trials on its efficacy against the respiratory disease, the Department of Health said. Health Undersecretary Rosario Vergeire said the DOH is already formulating guidelines on which hospitals will conduct the trial.

video_title: AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccines arrive in the Philippines
description:
A total of 487,200 doses of the COVID-19 vaccine developed by Oxford University and British-Swedish pharmaceutical firm AstraZeneca have arrived in the Philippines. The vaccines are part of the supply allocated to the Philippines by the global vaccine-sharing COVAX scheme.

video_title: GMA NEWS COVID-19 Bulletin: Philippines’ COVID-19 cases top 11,000; recoveries near 2,000
description:
The number of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) cases in the Philippines breached the 11,000 mark on Monday after the Department of Health (DOH) reported 292 new cases, raising the total to 11,086.
 
Total recoveries also rose to 1,999 with 75 new recoveries, while the death toll climbed to 726 after seven more patients succumbed to the respiratory illness.

video_title: Vaccination during COVID-19 (Explainer Video) | WHO Philippines, UNICEF, DOH
description:
In cooperation with UNICEF and Department of Health, World Health Organization Philippines presents:
Vaccination during COVID-19
(Explainer Video)

❓ Why does my child need additional vaccine doses against measles, polio and rubella?
❓ Is it safe to vaccinate my child during COVID-19?
❓ What are the normal reactions after vaccination?
 
LISTEN to this conversation of mothers in the neighborhood to know the answers.
 
The vaccination campaign against measles, polio and rubella will start on February 1 in Regions III, IVA and NCR, and in the entire Visayas.

For more information, visit doh.gov.ph/mr-opv
 
#ChikitingLigtas #VaccinesWork

-----------------
❓ Bakit kailangan ng aking chikiting ang dagdag-bakuna kontra tigdas, polio at rubella?
❓ Ligtas bang pabakunahan ko ang aking anak ngayong may COVID-19?
❓ Anu-ano ang mga normal na reaction pagkatapos mabakunahan?
 
PAKINGGAN ang usapan ng magkakapitbahay na mommies para sa kasagutan!
 
Gaganapin kampanya ng pagbabakuna laban sa tigdas, polio at rubella simula February 1 sa Regions III, IVA at NCR, at sa buong Visayas. 
 
Para sa karagdagang impormasyon, bumisita sa doh.gov.ph/mr-opv

#ChikitingLigtas #VaccinesWork

video_title: China-donated COVID-19 vaccines arrive in Philippines
description:
For  more:
https://www.cgtn.com/video

A batch of Sinovac's COVID-19 vaccines donated by China arrived in the Philippines on Sunday, the first COVID-19 vaccines to reach the Southeast Asian country. Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte attended the handover ceremony. The country has been struggling to curb the spread of the virus and the delivery of the vaccine allows the Philippines to start mass vaccinations soon.

video_title: Insights on the COVID-19 pandemic in the Philippines from Dr Anna Ong-Lim
description:
Pediatric infectious disease expert Dr Anna Ong-Lim sat down with Yahoo Philippines to talk about the threats that the pandemic continues to pose on our country, an assessment of the current government’s response to the COVID crisis, and the steps that the current administration will need to take going to the post-pandemic era. 

Read more: https://ph.news.yahoo.com/dr-anna-ong-lim-on-govts-covid-response-iatf-and-challenges-for-next-admin-072850924.html

For more stories: https://ph.yahoo.com/

Follow us on our socials:
https://tiktok.com/@yahoosea
https://instagram.com/yahoosg
https://facebook.com/yahoolifestylesg
video_transcript:
So, the government has actually followed
the recommendations of the WHO in addressing the COVID-19 pandemic
by focusing on aspects like test, trace and treat. So with respect to testing, of course
we know that nobody actually had enough resources to make sure that there would be enough RT-PCRs available
for the number of people who needed the testing. And so, one of the things that had to happen
was to ensure that laboratory facilities would be available,
the reagents would be there and make sure that we had distribution
networks available so that different parts of the country
could access testing. With respect to treat, of course, there was a focus on making sure
that the staff were trained, we had enough people. The hospitals would have the facilities to be able
to isolate individuals who were infected with COVID-19, and that was a challenge,
which I think was quite well met. I think there was a lot of focus
on making sure that hospital-based care was going to be consistently available. So, a lot of effort was placed on defining the capacity of the hospital system with respect to
what would be allocated for COVID-19 beds, the kind of staffing
that was needed, making sure that there was enough supply of medications
and other personal protective equipment. However, with respect to tracing,
we know that we would have wanted more resources directed towards that, but there were efforts to get it online. Efforts continue.
But I think we can do much better. We keep hearing about contact tracers,
ending their contracts. And I think that just goes to show
that this was not really embedded into the infrastructure. The public reaction to some policies
has been mixed. The mixed reactions generally come from people not being able to understand the context about certain policy directions. So, I think a lot of effort really needs
to be invested in communicating with the public, talking to them about why certain things are being done and what the expected outcomes are. There have been some policies
that have really been supported by the public like, whenever there's a surge, people are really looking forward
to an announcement that a community quarantine would be implemented.
But for certain other policies, like right now, there's this discussion about No Vaccination, No Ride
or mandatory vaccination in the workplace. Those are obviously going into the realm
of affecting personal liberties. So, there are no easy answers to that. I think this needs to be
a matter of continuing dialog. I think if people feel like their reasons
are being heard, that they're being given options, then we’ll probably get
a better reaction from the public. So whenever there's a discussion about getting a policy online, a lot of it typically has to do with
how do you make sure that people are allowed more mobility
without increasing the risk of transmission? So, for example,
with the No Vaccination, No Ride policy, the considerations included the need to allow more people
to access public transport but at the same time realizing that we had limited options available. But we have to also think about
are we actually allowing or are we actually able to provide everybody with the opportunity
to be vaccinated already, has access been equal? So maybe when we get to that point,
we can say that the only reason why you're not vaccinated
is because it's your choice. Then, a policy like that might make more sense. So, on the question of whether the IATF has been effective in actioning COVID-19 mandates, I think it's useful to have a structure like that because you have the key people, the key decision makers available within the group so that the communications don't have to go across
so many different levels and you can actually get that plan online
in the shortest possible time. I really got to appreciate the fact that you had
all of these decision makers available at a single time conducting a discussion
on various aspects of key issues. But I guess we're all still learning about this pandemic
until now, and I think the
the real issue is that we can only work on or make a decision based on what's available
in terms of the knowledge at that time. We know that the IATF actually is in charge
of crafting policy, and the implementation is taken care of by a lot of the different agencies
and the local government units. So, I think it would have helped if there was more input from the LGUs. Of course, they're represented in the IATF
but there are so many different LGUs with different capacities
and different realities on the ground, and I think that's really a problem. So, maybe in those instances
where people think that the response was not adequate or could have been improved,
I think, maybe one way to think about this if you consider the context,
was that the best possible decision at that time, and I'd like to believe
that usually the answer is yes. So, with respect to the core strategy of the IATF, I think if you look at how
they've been making their decisions, the goal has really been to make sure
that we have the least number of deaths, and this is the same goal
that many different countries have. And at the same time, balancing this need with respect to healthcare outcomes with the need
also to make sure that we have a working economy. So, that's a difficult balance
to achieve, actually. Any new administration that comes in will need to be able
to get the public to buy into their policies by making sure that communication is a focus. So, I think the new administration
can focus on two critical things. First is investing in the telecommunications
infrastructure that supports healthcare needs. We want to be able to count on information
technology, to capture data, to record data, to share data. I mean, if you think about the way
our vaccine records are constructed now, something very simple
doesn't need second thought, but it's a struggle for us to get that information
into the hands of every individual. I think it's also going to be very important
for the incoming administration to think about how they can better support
healthcare professionals. So, make sure that the people who are already here
get what's due to them, and also make it more attractive for people
who are thinking about a career, to consider healthcare professions
and staying to help the country. One of the solutions is really to make sure
that universal health care is implemented. With that, a patient can expect that at any point in the system, there's going to be a way for them
to get their needs addressed. And so, if we can fast track implementation of this system, make sure people can access it, then we can expect
that there will be a more efficient solution to the continuing demands of COVID-19
and all these other healthcare problems. So, in comparison to different countries
in the region in Asia and even globally, I think one of our big pluses
has been keeping our mortality rate low. I think this is really a tribute
to how well our healthcare professionals have been able to manage the cases
that come their way in the hospitals. But I wish we had the resources
that other countries had with respect to tracing, because this would really have been able to limit
the cases that we've had to deal with and allow this to focus
what resources we had on the more severe cases. I think our healthcare system will do its best to handle
another large scale outbreak, based on the response of our healthcare
professionals. I don't think we can count on many more beds
being available or more resources being available, and as much as I wish that we had more people, that's going to take time to train. But I think the public can always count
on best effort from healthcare professionals to carry us through any crisis. So, from what I've observed, our government's plan to exit
the pandemic is pretty similar to what other governments are thinking about doing,
shifting from a pandemic emergency response to a mindset that thinks about COVID-19
as something that will stay and learning to live with it
to the best extent possible. So, just thinking about how you deal with other diseases that continue
to be a problem like dengue or measles, life doesn't stop
because those diseases are around. We just need to be able to figure out
how to manage them while allowing people the mobility
that they need to be able to function in society. So unfortunately, COVID-19 is a lot more contagious. So, we need the help of all of these public health
measures that we can put online so that we can contain it, at the same time
allowing people to move around. So, the new government
can think about how to make what we do now more efficient in the effort
to be able to live with COVID-19. If you think about public transport, for example, there can be a lot of interventions
about making sure that it's less crowded and we make it less likely that people who take
public transport are going to catch COVID-19 as they go about their daily routines. We can talk about making sure
that regulations are in place so that air quality is much, much better,
and people don't have to give it a second thought that they might get COVID-19
just by being out in public. So, when we think about when the Philippines
is likely to return to normal, I feel like there are two important issues
that need to align. First, we need to get people,
more people to be vaccinated, and then second, we need to get the virus
to cooperate and not mutate any further so that the protection that we can expect
from vaccines continues to be in place.

video_title: Philippines grants EUA to AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine | 24 Oras
description:
The Philippine Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has granted emergency use authorization for AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine, its director general, Dr. Eric Domingo, announced on Thursday.

This makes AstraZeneca, a British pharmaceutical firm, the second company to secure an EUA in the Philippines after Pfizer BioNTech.

Domingo said AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine, which it developed with Oxford University, has posted an efficacy rate of 70% after first dose.

video_title: The New Normal in Philippine Education Caused by the COVID-19 Pandemic
description:
Every child has the right to education. However, the case isn’t the same in the middle of a pandemic. In this new episode of #AsianMoments series, let’s take a look at the “new normal” in the education field that the Filipino youth’s adapting today.

This video is brought to you by KLIPP.tv: Your Gateway to Asia.

***

KLIPP.tv is an online TV that provides content on culture, business, and human interest. Diverse stories of different people in the Philippines and in Asia are articulated through the media services that KLIPP.tv provides.

KLIPP.tv, your gateway to Asia.

#Asia #Blog #Philippines #CoVid19 #Pandemic #Feature #CoVid19News
video_transcript: [Music] hello there everyone welcome to another episode of asian moments today clip tv will take a glimpse of the new method of education in the philippines since the onset optical fit19 pandemic last year it has been a year since the coveted 19 pandemic ravaged the whole world everything has changed economies came to a near crash a lot of businesses closed shop even the educational system suffered a big slump as schools were prohibited from holding regular face-to-face classes in order not to hinder the continuous learning process a new system of teaching was put into place instead of regular classes in school classrooms online learning is now the new form of teaching teachers reach out to their students by way of the internet new teleconferencing platforms have replaced the regular classrooms education secretary leonor briones with this system came the modular lesson scheme where modules for the different subjects are being prepared by teachers and then later distributed to students to work on these are then returned to the teachers for checking and compilation this would seem exciting and workable for filipino families who can afford to buy good cell phones tablets or laptop computers and also capable of purchasing a good and efficient internet connection but how about those families who cannot afford to buy gadgets and internet connection here we see again the great disparity between those who can afford and those who cannot students who do not have the capability to possess these gadgets and access the good data connections will be at the verge of being left behind the department of education or deped planned to purchase air time from local radio stations to be used as alternate teaching venues but these also presents another problem because of the high costs of radio broadcast airtime there too teaching will be a one-way affair as the learners could not communicate back to their teachers the growing concern now from both parents and teachers is the seeming deterioration of the quality of instruction in the country if and when the pandemic will continually prevent face-to-face classroom classes to make things worse online classes in public schools average 30 to 40 students per session this is an enormous task to surmount on the part of the teachers after a year into the pandemic uncertainty still exists within the philippine educational system what is in store for the filipino youth what contingency plans does the government have in the event that this health problem will not end soon no one knows what the future holds for the philippine educational system will this be a temporary setback that can be easily reversed or will it be the start of a deteriorated form of education for the filipino youth reporting from the philippines i am william santos and this is asian moments on click tv your gateway to asia [Music]

video_title: TUKLAS LUNAS: 3 Promising Philippine Plants vs. COVID-19
description:
Bilang isang biodiversity hotspot, likas na mayaman sa halamang-gamot ang Pilipinas. Sa ilalim ng “Tuklas Lunas” o Philippine Drug Discovery and Development Program ng Department of Science and Technology, kasalukuyang pinag-aaralan ng mga eksperto ang ilang halamang gamot sa bansa na nakagagamot ng iba’t ibang sakit.

Alamin natin ang tatlong local plants na kasalukuyang namang pinag-aaralan bilang gamot sa coronavirus disease 2019.

Subscribe to our official YouTube channel, https://www.youtube.com/UNTVNewsandRescue.

Be the first to know about the latest updates on COVID-19 pandemic, lockdowns, community quarantine, new normal, and Serbisyong Bayanihan. 

We Serve the People. We Give Glory To God!
#LagingHandaPH #UNTVNewsandRescue #COVID19PH

For news update, visit: https://www.untvweb.com/news/

Check out our official social media accounts:
https://www.facebook.com/UNTVNewsRescue
https://www.twitter.com/untvnewsrescue
https://www.youtube.com/untvnewsandrescue
Instagram account - @untvnewsrescue

Feel free to share but do not re-upload.
video_transcript: THE TUKLAS LUNAS PROGRAM  OF THE DEPARTMENT OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY, WE HAVE A LIST OF MORE THAN FIVE HUNDRED PLANTS THAT,   THROUGH ORAL HISTORY,  WE KNOW HAS PROPERTIES  TO CURE VARIOUS ILLNESSES. WE DISTRIBUTED THESE PLANTS TO UNIVERSITIES WHO PARTICIPATED IN THE TUKLAS LUNAS PROGRAM OR THE DRUG DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM. IN THIS PROGRAM, WE ASSIGNED PLANTS THAT THEY WOULD STUDY ESPECIALLY PLANTS ABUNDANT IN THEIR PLACES. ALMOST TWENTY UNIVERSITIES ARE INVOLVED IN THIS, AND THE FIRST THING THEY DO IS TO STUDY, THEY WOULD IDENTIFY AND EXTRACT THEY WOULD CHECK THE ACTIVE INGREDIENTS. AFTER THEY HAVE IDENTIFIED THE ACTIVE INGREDIENTS, THEY WOULD TEST FOR THE TOXICITY AND THE HARMFUL EFFECTS. AN EXAMPLE IS THE ASTHMA PLANT, WHICH HAS AN APPROVAL AS A HEALTH SUPPLEMENT PARTICULARLY FOR DENGUE. HOWEVER, SINCE IT WILL BE USED FOR A DIFFERENT ILLNESS SPECIFICALLY COVID-19 IT STILL NEEDS AN APPROVAL FROM THE FDA FOR CLINICAL TRIALS THE FIVE-LEAVED CHASTE TREE HAS BEEN REGISTERED AS A REMEDY OR A MEDICINE FOR COUGH AND RELATED RESPIRATORY AILMENTS OR SYMPTOMS. BUT THAT IS APPLICABLE FOR COUGH IT STILL NEEDS CLEARANCE FROM THE FDA THE TRIAL FOR THE FIVE-LEAVED CHASTE TREE IS READY THEY ARE PREPARED, WE HAVE FUNDS FOR THE TRIAL, THEY ARE READY FOR THE CLINICAL TRIALS, THEY HAVE THE APPROVAL FROM THE ETHICS BOARD. THE STUDY ON VCO STARTED IN THE LATE 1990s  THE LATE DOCTOR CONRADO DAYRIT CONDUCTED THE STUDY. HE CONDUCTED TRIALS ON HIV PATIENTS IN SAN LAZARO. THE ONGOING CLINICAL TRIALS ARE CONDUCTED IN TWO PLACES ONE IS AT THE PGH AND THE SANTA ROSA COMMUNITY HOSPITAL. AT SANTA ROSA THE TARGET SAMPLES ARE 90 PATIENTS. OUT OF THE 90 TARGETED PATIENTS, WE ONLY HAVE 30 PATIENTS. WE HAVE DIVIDED THE SAMPLES FIFTEEN ARE TAKING VCO, WHILE THE OTHER FIFTEEN ARE NOT TAKING VCO OVER 28 DAYS. ALMOST HALF OF THE PATIENTS WENT HOME AND WERE CURED OF COVID-19. WE JUST NEED TO STUDY THE EFFECTIVENESS OF VCO. VCO, ASTHMA PLANT,  AND FIVE-LEAVED CHASTE TREE  HAVE ANTI-VIRAL PROPERTIES OR LET’S SAY ANTI-BACTERIAL PROPERTIES. IF WE LISTEN TO SUGGESTIONS FROM PEOPLE, SOME ARE RECOMMENDING VARIOUS PLANTS LIKE TURMERIC, MORINGA, ALTHOUGH I HAVE NO IDEA IF THESE CAN CURE COVID-19. BUT THESE ARE THE POPULAR PLANTS THAT THEY SUGGEST FOR CLINICAL TRIALS, EVEN BITTER GOURD. SO THESE ARE THE INFORMATION  ABOUT OUR MEDICINAL PLANTS. WE HAVE A RICH BIODIVERSITY  WE HAVE MANY RESOURCES, HOWEVER, CONDUCTING CLINICAL TRIALS ARE COSTLY. WE NEED TO SELECT PLANTS AND CHECK IF ANYONE IS INTERESTED TO CONDUCT TRIALS.

video_transcript: the department of health reports on tuesday august 2 the country's first two cases of the highly transmissible omicron ba 0.2.75 the new subvariant is known as centaurus due to its rapid spread the oh officer in charge maria rosario vegeta says the two cases are from western visayas and have already recovered she adds their exposure and travel histories are still being verified ba 0.2.75 is another omicron offshoot first detected in india in may and has since spread to around 10 countries initial studies show ba 0.2.75 is more transmissible and has more potential to evade vaccine protection but experts say vaccination is still the best way to avoid infection hospitalization and deaths despite the rise in cases the entire philippines remains at low risk for covet 19 while metro manila is at moderate risk for the virus

find ways to connect communities which we never thought before that could be done so what we're trying to set up now is a conversation on fgd with students that we put them online and the interviewer is coming from manila so i think that creates uh a new way of doing uh this kind of research uh as uh as dr tan have mentioned they have to do on different narratives of people during this crisis so yeah to to move forward our discussion thank you very much dr portus for sharing uh we got the question from uh dr hemant kumar uh what is it that we could learn from the philippines in terms of fighting uh more effectively and fighter kovid and a jobless scenario well in in the philippines now that is still a very very big debate as we are still at the middle of the crisis what is certain is as far as surveys are concerned hunger and people went up there were so many uncertainties that people see in the future and the government is trying to count on providing support to communities but we all know that this is not also enough there are initiatives here and there but i i think we would rather reserve a full uh discussion on this one on our second webinar actually because uh our second webinar for dr kumar will will focus basically on the issue of how do we attend to people directly during this crisis so that would be the focus of our next webinar on the issue of social protection and we will be inviting scholars from both countries to tackle on that issue as we tackle also i think later also on the next sessions we will have on the issue of economic stimulus package being prepared by these two countries but thank you for raising that issue um for now in the interest of time how i wish i can continue this conversation uh with us uh but just before we close uh our session this will be a question for uh dr sachin dr malhotra and of course dr portus that we would like to hear your final words and the final thoughts on this uh this is a question i would like to post to everybody and i think people are don't want to be stuck so much with a crisis they want to move so the question i would like and probably could be your wrapping up statement for our webinar uh if the crisis is an opportunity to innovate or introduce new ways of seeing acting and working what change would you like to see in our post pandemic world probably we can may i invite dr sachin then before that dr if there's an opportunity to innovate what is it that you would like to see acting or working that change that you would like to see in the post-pandemic world dr sachin uh uh thank you uh thanks a lot uh professor agua it is it is uh extremely pleasant to um be part of this uh initiative and as i said in the beginning and i whenever you were mentioning uh uh dr agua about the internal debates in philippines on traditional versus modern medicine i would very much request you to begin contributing papers as professor malhotra mentioned that the idea is to engage in discussions so i would very much like to invite you uh as a as a sociologist uh to uh uh to contribute and reflect on the nuances of these debates in philippines how you see uh the the challenges and what kind of possible uh traditional medicines are there let us focus on on on health to be very specific but later on we can we can work out so uh in my uh perspective the way forward should be to understand uh we going forward in terms of leveraging uh science technology and innovation for our work uh as a social scientist trying to see how that can really help for instance i also mentioned about fintech and fintech contributing the technology in the finance sector is helping bringing in financial inclusion for everyone so how philippines and the society can achieve this in a major way i also had an opportunity of of seeing the communities that are there in philippines uh particularly the coastal areas where uh much more sort of convergence india and philippines may have because we have recently introduced coast led development program in india so how coastal communities can contribute to that these are some of the areas which fall very much into the overall strategies and philippines is also part of asean so with that our bilateral and the regional cooperation comes in in a major way for us to go forward and we share a lot of commonalities as uh professor bhushan patwathan mentioned so i think it is important and there are several synergies and commonalities complementarities that we can bring together for collective benefits so so in my view we can combine some of these areas for a greater analysis and greater understanding thank you very much dr sachin that is well said may i go to uh dr portugal mamo that yeah yeah the question is what i want to see post covered okay yes um i don't think we'll go back to our past no uh i don't think kavit will get away in the next three to five years so we should embrace it while we look at it as something that has devastated our economy we should also look at the more positive sides like there are also positive sides people began to you know uh work on their hobbies they become gardeners cook they embroider they crochet so all of these things that they were doing they were not doing before you know they are able to do now and families now i think because they are all locked up inside the house no they have now the reason to bond and they become closer and they converse a lot no in my family you know this is the only time that you all really get to sit on the table and say anything and uh you know get to know each other's day and we're all working from home so it's it's it's nice to know that you know you're surrounded by your children where before know they just you know they go anywhere so you when they come home it's night time and when they go it's very early the morning so we don't have any conversation at all but now that they are locked up now we have a lot of time to converse and we have a lot of time to really get to know each other well so i think um we're we're seeing a world no that will embrace kovid no i you know as dr patuardon has mentioned we don't even have evidence that rem disappear will be a good vaccine so uh it's really difficult to say that it will end so my outlook is that let's embrace it no and let's turn the negative aspect into something more positive so we researchers we social scientists are you know in fact enjoying it because you know we are able to go to india virtually we're able to invite you without this pandemic maybe we it will be difficult uh to conduct this uh or to mount this webinar because you know you have to travel or we have to travel there we spend a lot but now with the technology uh we are really more connected but of course uh technologies have their pitfalls like my young you know just went in the beginning no so i think that's also part of you know adjusting to this situation hopefully we'll get better connections and hopefully there will be continuing um and pre uh uh adoption to this technology uh our children are of course uh experiencing difficulty because of this now you the digital and blended learning and the parents get to get a lot of stress because they're the ones responsible in monitoring their children but uh i think our government our department of education is trying to correct this and hopefully there will be more measures or more policies now that will make the technology work not only in education but in all other aspects of our human life so kovid will be here let us embrace it thank you thank you very much dr portus you are right my wife is very happy actually during the pandemic i have not traveled outside of our home for the last seven months yes it's a blessing for all of us dr malhotra please thank you professor guha in fact it has been a very nice session today and we could listen to different viewpoints also and different viewpoints or some stage do appear to be converging and diverging also that's one thing secondly i feel we are talking about normal going back to the normal that existed or will there be a new normal also and new normal will become normal in a few days time that's that's another thing and i i do think that there is going to be a lot of change in our thinking the thinking on health and hygiene as uh dr tan very rightly said culture and governance they are going to have a tremendous change uh thinking on education there were times we were talking about online quality of online teaching there are times now we are talking about high standards of online teaching and uh dr porches was making a mention about that i do feel that international relations international institutions right they are going to have tremendous changes in days to come and maybe new collaborations and new partnerships will see many changes secondly the data that appears before us today in in the form of stories i think stories need to be further supported by evidence the data needs to be verified in days to come and that would be happening so i see a lot many collaborations in the world not only taking place in the area of research but also in the area of health and hygiene so they are going to be the points for tomorrow as i said under athena the learning from india can be or the prime minister of india is that that in place of few towers of development will have vast fields of development and opportunities for the greater number of masses so there is a new understanding on environment also i think which has grown during this period of six months whether polluting the environment first and thinking of the remedies thereafter and investing heavily or spending heavily on curing the environment or what could be the possible solutions before us since dr porchu was making a mention about family bonding getting more deep and intense we have an evidence which contradicts that statement also i know number of papers have been published which talk about uh domestic violence during the pandemic times right so so evidences are quite diverse in nature and i think in days to come there'll be further more researches and maybe if there are instances of moving away from the journal statements or the general findings then the reasoning behind those findings would also need a little little more underpinning and a little deeper evidence behind it so with these words i'll thank you all for being with us and making so nice and so touching presentations in fact not only euro diet but also i mean touching you everywhere your mind and heart both so i i see i have i've started our con we had started our conversation with our philippines partner by saying that you look too good while smiling and i would like to repeat that sentence that this world must be very healthy it must have hygiene and it should be smiling all the time as you people are smiling right now before i ask so all the very best i'm looking forward to have two more sessions with you and number of wonderful presentations projects and and i will emphasize joint publications i said it in our conversation earlier also that whatever is being presented is to be finally converted into a publication and this is a relationship must be taken i agree i agree thank you thank you very much thank you very much dr malhotra what a very interesting message you have uh given us and the prospect of the cooperation between the two countries the greatest challenge for a facilitator and a moderator and session like this is to provide a synthesis you know and how would you synthesize sets up it's a wonderful presentation so substantive presented by our speakers i might not be able to do justice to all of that but these are some of the quick points that came to mind when i was listening to all our speakers as we battle with kovid there is an important role on political leadership i think both countries affirmed that because they have different experiences then there should be a convergence of governance in fact dr sachin habito it should be a seamless convergence in governance then the issue of cultural connect and disconnect of what we are doing i think that has been shown by speakers from the two countries then also the issue and the question we raised how do we propose policy what do we mean by evidence-based because what is evident might be changing from one perspective and one experiences as well and i think we have to interrogate the facts related to it then the next is in the question of where is people in all these questions that we would like to do i think our colleagues have emphasized at the end of the day this is all about our people and they should benefit out of the debate and they should benefit from the researches that we are doing i think our colleague also in india and partly here in the philippines have talked about the rule of science and technology you know the more we should use it in the service of humanity especially in the height of this crisis then it has been said that while we have to do the localization of our strategies because people at the end of the day are in our local communities let us not also forget the need for global solidarity and of course an interesting perspective i'm sure it will be taken up in future discussions it's really the issue of dependence on medicines and the discourse on traditional health you know and the modern technology and medicine and how do you combine this for the benefit of the people i think in both countries there are really clear debates on all of this and how this being deployed and i think uh social scientists and both divide could really profit more on this issue and if you'd like to pick up again that there we should not allow the monoculture monocultural dominance because i think at this time of the crisis we have to encourage a perspective of diversity of people and of culture because at the end of the day this is about we in the social sciences would like to contribute in building a just in the humane society the crisis is just a test of our solidarity this has been a very interesting afternoon for both countries for both organizations the philippine social science council and the indian council of social science research this is our first and we are coming up again future activities in the coming months so please follow us in our website and it will be announced in both organizations the next that we have lined up actually as initiatives that we would like to undertake in the coming days one would delve on the social protection issue during this time upon them i think there are rich experiences that you could imagine uh both countries could share what worked well what did not work well and how the social scientist also contributed on this discourse then on the third that we would like to do is the issue of the economic stimulus package you know everybody is talking about it but if you ask people in the street they actually don't understand about it it seemed to be a discourse up there left to people economies like dr sachin but how do we filter it down and what does it exactly mean for ordinary people that may uplift their problem on mental health because like as i've said in this part of the world people are just so worried what is the prospect of the future for them of course uh as mentioned also by dr malhotra there will be future initiatives that both collaboration likes to produce from publication to joint researches and other more we could explore because there's a lot for us to learn from each other and this is where the vibrance of the social science is coming to the picture of course i'd like to thank our resource person so in despite their busy schedule really tried to join us in this very important discussions we have we would like to thank also those who followed us in this webinar on our page especially those who asked questions and for joining us for this timely and relevant discussion today i hope you have profited much from our discussions we are not here to provide answers to all questions we are here i think a social scientist as we always say we are here a good discussion is a discussion that generates great questions and that's i think what we have achieved for today for everybody that joined us in this webinar we also request everyone to accomplish our brief evaluation form to help us improve uh in the way we are running this event as we will be coming up with future activities still the link to our evaluation is flashed on your screen but it will also be flashed on the website that we are using for this conversation only those who are able to submit the evaluation form will be given certificate of attendance the evaluation form will remain well they say five o'clock we can extend a little of it because it's almost five o'clock here in the philippines uh for people to be able to fill up that one again those who would like to follow this webinar we will be posting uh on our web the recording of this seminar we asked everybody that would like to review on this discourse and would like to share it also to their colleagues that the the video conversation during the seminar will be made available to all of us i think i could only say at this point thank you very much for everybody for joining us today and for the two leaders of organizations the philippine social science council headed by dr portus and the indian council of social science research for bringing together this initiative we are so excited to look forward at the prospect of this cooperation again as they said in crisis it will bring us opportunities and for us in the philippine social science council this is the opportunity that we're able to stumble in the midst of the covet crisis on that note ladies and gentlemen thank you very much i think it's now a good afternoon in both countries we have finally come and concluded in here and this is uh mario agua from the philippines saying thank you very much for sharing with us to all our research persons to those who followed us in the conversation i hope that you find this activity of ours this afternoon a productive thank you very much thank you very much may i take this opportunity to also thank dr badukar now he's been very supportive in coordinating this summer dr madokar how are you hi thank you so much thank you everybody thank you

video_title: Philippines’ COVID-19 tally now at 563,456 with 2,288 new cases | 24 Oras
description:
The Department of Health on Monday announced 2,288 new COVID-19 infections, raising the nationwide total to 563,456, as six laboratories failed to submit data on time.

Latest data from the DOH showed that total recoveries also increased to 522,874 after 33 more patients defeated the respiratory illness, while six fatalities brought the death toll to 12,094.
